plist.p: Dear, ladies and gentlemen, welcome to E.ON First Quarter Results 2012. At our customer's request, this conference will be recorded. As a reminder all participants will be in a listen-only mode. After the presentation, there will be an opportunity to ask questions.
May I now hand you over to Mr. Sascha Bibert, Head of Investor Relations, who will lead this conference. Please go ahead, sir.

Yes. Thank you and good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to our first quarter results. Today, we have reported a good set of numbers, confirming the headline earnings we have pre-released a few days ago. The pre-release was due to our interpretation of the German Ad Hoc Regulation. In general, all relevant information which might have a significant influence on the share price need to be published immediately. Criteria that are used in such an assessment include deviations against expectations but also against prior year. With underlying net income up 27%, and a similar gap against the first market expectations we had at that point in time, we decided that the criteria was fulfilled and an ad hoc release was necessary.

With respect to the presentation, you would have noticed a slight change in the order of the slides used for this conference call. During his comments, Marcus will focus on the key developments for the group, while the detailed segment discussion has been moved into the backup.
At the same time, two new slides has been added giving some color on our operating environment, as well as key developments we expect to be relevant in the further development of the year.
With that I hand over to our CFO, Marcus Schenck.

Yes. Hello, also from my side. Thank you for joining Sascha and myself to this quarterly results call. As Sascha said, the first quarter 2012 was a good start into the year for our company with EBITDA up 9% to €3.8 billion, underpinning our basic stance that we have passed through the trough in 2011.

On a constant portfolio basis, i.e. adjusting basically for the disposal of UK Central Networks last year, the increase is even more pronounced, namely about 15%. I will run you through the detail drivers of Group EBITDA at a later stage.

Underlying EPS increased by 27% to almost $0.90 for this first quarter. Operating cash flow was down 51% to €0.4 billion, however, this is solely driven by a single technical effect. I will as usual explain this position in more detail later on, however, just one remark already at this stage. This development is a result of an extraordinary withholding tax payment, which we have to make in the first quarter. We expect to fully recoup it in the second half of the year with subsequent positive implications for operating cash flow and of course also net debt.

As usual, Q1 was characterized by relatively muted investment activity, with group CapEx unchanged at €1.2 billion. Hence, the main reason for the increase in economic net debt was the weaker operating cash flow, driven by the aforementioned tax payment and also by increased pension provisions. In light of this positive first quarter, we confirm our outlook for the full year 2012.

In the first quarter, commodity and power prices were moved by essentially two key events. First of all, the cold spell in Europe and then secondly continued tensions in the Middle East. The latter, had an especially pronounced impact on the oil markets with a barrel of oil, which started the year at around $110 peaking at $125, with the climax of the tensions with Iran.

Core markets were not impacted by the political situation in the Middle East. A ton of API2 started the year at $117 heading down to the low U.S. $111 in sync with the initially warm winter in Europe. At the end of the quarter, prices were back at levels as of early January.

These overall relatively low coal prices, from our perceptive, can be explained mainly by volumes coming from the U.S. where cheap shale gas makes gas-fire generation more competitive, leading to less coal-based power generation and consequently excess coal volumes being pushed into the Atlantic basin.

European gas in the forward markets showed a clear upward trend in the first quarter, starting the year at €26 per megawatt hour, the one year forward increased to over €28 in March. The drivers that we see for this development were the cold spell in February in Europe, the continued tight situation in Japan, reduced LNG availability and then finally also the Elgin-Franklin outage in the British North Sea.

CO2 showed an interim rally in anticipation of positive results from political process around the introduction of an EU-wide energy efficiency directive. The initial plan of the Commission was to include a CO2 set aside for the third phase of the trading into the overall package. Positive sentiment, therefore, moved the price up to €10 per ton, only to end the quarter at the level where it started the year when it became clear that your position against the directive is currently too strong.

In the Central European power markets, power prices also saw an interim rally, fueled by the cold spell in February. This did not have a lasting impact on prices for 2013 where the quarter then ended where it started, basically, at a price below €52 per megawatt hour.

Now some words on the cold spell that I mentioned several times so far. During the first two weeks in February, Europe was hit by a period of cold weather, with temperatures being 5 to 7 degrees Celsius below average for several days. In particular, in France, we saw the highest demand ever, more than 100 gigawatts. During these days, the supply situation has been extremely tight.

According to our analysis, Europe could cope with the situation only due to the extremely high availability of power plants. In average we experienced a higher degree of unplanned outages to the cold weather and prudent behavior of the market operators.

At E.ON, for example, we managed to switch some of our gas plants to oil in order to cope with a gas import shortage from Russia that was announced at the same time. In a nutshell, Europe managed to keep lights on and houses warm but in the last decade the supply situation was never as tight as in February.

In the Nordic markets, area prices moved down €1 per megawatt hour in the course of the quarter to end up at around €40 per megawatt hour for the 2013 delivery, also with the interim peak on the back of the cold spell. The hydro situation by now is extremely good this year, with reservoir levels being at peak levels.

So finally to our hedging. As you will notice, not a lot happens for the years 2012 and 2013 as we were already well hedged both in Nordic as well as Central Europe for those years. This is different for the year 2014. Sufficient liquidity allowed us to advance our hedge ratios in both market areas. The increase, for example, in the Central European region from 20% to 30% hedged as per year end 2011 to 60% to 70% hedged as per end of the quarter. While this has led to a slight reduction of the average key price from €55 down to €54, I would consider this a very good result, compared to currently traded forward prices.

Let us now turn over to our operations. Exploration and production is one of the key earnings drivers for the coming years. In the current year, we are however experiencing challenges in our North Sea operations. As I'm sure you have heard, the last UK field Elgin-Franklin, which is operated by Total and which is 5.2% co-owned by E.ON, the field had to stop production due to a gas leak. Total is the final stages of preparing the kill well operation. Execution of the relief wells is progressing according to plan but the completion of these wells will take several months.

We are also experiencing challenges with our participation in the new oil and gas field, Skarv in Norway, which we are developing with BP as the operator. Weather conditions in the winter and early spring have not been favorable and made the installation of the risers basically impossible. Risers are those pipes connecting the wellheads on the sea floor with the FPSO. By now, eight out of the required 13 risers have been installed. There are also problems with getting government approval for use of planned staff capacity offshore during the installation phase.

We're now hoping for more stable, i.e. quiet weather conditions in the spring and summer months and are actively trying to solve the staff capacity issue. This mentioned problems are the main reason for the delay of the planned operation start of Skarv into the fourth quarter, according to the operator BP.

Lübz is one of our key strategic growth areas and an area where we are committing substantial amount of new capital. Therefore, I'm happy to report that we saw very good first quarter, in terms of wind load factors across the board. The net load factor of our whole wind fleet improved from 30.4% to 36.8%. This was a result of good wind availability but also of further improved average availability. The contribution to this performance also came from offshore wind in Europe. Here we registered good net load factors improving from 39.3% to numbers as high as 45.1%. For instance, the availability of our Nordic offshore fleet was almost 99% in this period.

In our conventional Generation business, we have been experiencing problems with our Brokdorf nuclear power plant, which is currently in an unplanned extended maintenance shutdown. After finding some broken fuel rod springs in one of the cooling ponds of our Brokdorf nuclear power station, we are currently checking the situation regarding the condition of these fuel rod springs in the reactor's core. While the situation did not have an impact on the first quarter results, we're expecting the full year impact of this to be in the range of low to mid-double digit million euros.

Last, but not least, I would like to talk about another important pillar of our strategy, which is the outside Europe expansion. Here we have made a significant step ahead with the signing of the deal with MPX on the creation of a joint venture company, which is foreseen to build 11 gigawatt of new capacity for the Brazilian market in this decade. After the initial basic agreement from January, this marks the conclusion of the negotiations, including an agreement on the organizational structure.

At this stage, we can confirm all the operational principles outlined at the start of the year. To finalize the establishment of the joint venture some financial and legal steps will have to be concluded. The strategic work has already started and the two companies expect all outstanding actions to be completed by June 2012, hence, we do expect the transaction to close by the end of the second quarter.

Let me now turn to the developments of group EBITDA in the first quarter and compare it to the first quarter of 2011. And let's start with the negatives. The largest negative impact was in our nuclear power portfolio. Here we have to differentiate between two effects: Firstly, we saw the impact of last year's shutdowns of the power plant Isar 1 and Unterweser, which were still producing in Q1 of 2011. These 4 terawatt hours that now fell away in Q1 of 2012 and that basically leads to a loss in margins in Q1 of this year. Secondly, we mainly saw the impact of falling average achieved power prices for the Central European outright portfolio.
The second negative, albeit far not so prominent, is the expected reduction of Q1 profitability at our E&P operation. Here, mainly the low availability of the Njord and Rita fields takes its toll.

Now to the positives. The by far biggest swing comes from our Supply and Sales business, which manages the long-term gas contracts. Last year's first quarter was severely burdened by this business because at that time we did not have any renegotiation success in the numbers.

Supply and Sales lost around €470 million in Q1 of 2011 as basically 100% of the non-spot related volumes sourced from our long-term contracts were based on too high oil-linked prices. Since then, we have successfully renegotiated roughly two-thirds of these volumes. The reflection of these renegotiations is the €340 million improvement of EBITDA at Supply and Sales.

In this context, please remember that our renegotiation with Statoil became effective as of January 1 this year. And, again, to avoid misunderstanding we are reporting Supply and Sales now within the optimization line in the segment Optimization and Trading.

Also within the gas business, we recorded a one-off gain from the revaluation of three participations in the context of separating Open Grid Europe. Proprietary trading improved compared to the weak first quarter of 2011. And in the UK we saw a net positive effect of €20 million. This is essentially the net result of two bigger movements.

Firstly, we observed the deconsolidation of UK Central Networks, which had contributed a positive €170 million still through the first quarter of last year. Remember, it was deconsolidated with the effect from 1 of April 2011 on.

Secondly, we saw a slightly higher positive effect from the improvement of margins in our UK sales business. This peak year-on-year delta was the result of a weak first quarter at UK sales in 2011 and price increases, which took effect later on in this year – later on in the year.

These higher prices positively impacted two of the three months of this year's first quarter. Our 6% cut of electricity prices took effect as per end of February. Therefore, the remainder of the year is expected to be far less outstanding in terms of year-on-year performance. Also, we will see additional cost for energy efficiency measures during the rest of the year.

Russia profited mainly from the contribution of new power plants, which were commissioned in the later course of 2011. The remaining positive delta is mainly related to an improvement of the other consolidation position at group level.

On the following Slides 5 and 6, we reconcile as usual the net income starting from EBITDA. Our economic net interest expense was basically unchanged. Net book gains came down strongly compared to last year. Last the position benefited predominantly from the disposal of the remaining Gazprom shares.

Restructuring improved compared to Q1 of 2011 and in this context please remember that we booked a large restructuring provision in the fourth quarter last year. Our reported tax rate of 20%, compared to 22% in Q1 of 2011, came down slightly. This is mainly a reflection of the weaker earnings development especially related to the situation in exploration and production.

Just like in Q1 2011, nothing to comment on for this quarter in terms of discontinued operations. Central Networks are larger – or last larger disposal was still fully reflected in last year's first quarter results and deconsolidated quickly as the deal closed very fast.

Moving on the reconciliation of underlying net income. In the underlying net income the positive impact of the EBITDA improvement feeds through fully to the net income line, with depreciation and net interest basically unchanged. The additional improvement at the net income level is driven by the lower taxes.

Let me now run you through the development of our operating cash flow on Chart number 8. Starting from the €900 million of operating cash flow in Q1 2011, the first effect is the higher cash-effective EBITDA. Then we see a group of working capital effects, partially related to the current period, partially to developments in Q1 of last year.

Let me take them one by one. In the UK we reduced our coal inventories. This is driven by the biomass conversion of the plant Ironbridge and lower production at the Kingsnorth plant. Then at Optimization and Trading, we reduced coal as well as gas inventories and we also increased the payables in gas procurement.
In Russia and Czechia we had negative working capital effects last year, which we mentioned in previous calls caused by regulatory changes which were not repeated this year.

In Germany, we have a timing issue with passing on higher EEG costs to the final customer. The UK pension funding effect also relates to last year where we have to put additional cash into the fund. The lower interest payments relate mostly to the early redemption fees, which we paid for the buyback of E.ON bonds last year.
So before I come to the €1.6 billion tax effect, we observed a quite material improvement in operating cash flow to a level of €2.1 million, which is roughly a 130% increase over the Q1 2011 number.

Now, what is this €1.6 billion tax payment? In the context of our 2011 full year accounts of the E.ON AG, we distributed dividend from certain subsidiaries to the AG. This causes a prepayment on E.ON's overall tax declaration for 2011. We expect to fully recoup these payments in the second half of 2012.

Now to our debt situation on Chart number 9. Compared to the position shown for fiscal year-end 2011, our economic net debt has increased by €1.2 billion. And here are the key moving parts. Group CapEx was unchanged compared to the prior year's first quarter at a level of €1.2 billion. Over 50% of the quarter's investments came from Renewables and Generation with Renewables responsible for 30% of Q1 CapEx. We currently have almost 1.8 gigawatt of capacity under construction in our Renewables business.

Operating cash flow for the reasons I mentioned, came in 51% below the Q1 2011 figure and only contributed €0.4 billion to the debt reduction. Divestments amounted to a positive €0.2 billion, pension provisions increased by €0.7 billion, with the main drivers here being the reduction of the benchmark bond yields, leading to a lower discount rate in Germany, where we see a 50 basis point reduction. Other effects added up to a positive of €0.1 billion.

I would like to highlight again at this stage that the very negative development of the operating cash flow, which is a main factor behind the overall net debt increase, is driven by factors that we expect to reverse in the course of the remainder of the year, putting the net debt development on a clear downwards trends.

Now finally to the outlook. We are confirming our 2012 EBITDA and underlying net income outlook. We continued to see EBITDA to come out in the flat €9.6 billion to €10.2 billion range and we also confirmed the €2.3 billion to €2.7 billion range for the underlying net income for 2012.

With regard to the individual segment outlook, I would like to highlight that we do see a certain risk for E&P. The reasons behind this uncertainty I have explained earlier in the call. Just to remind you we have uncertainty on the timing of the restart of Elgin, as well as the actual start of production at Skarv.

For both cases, we expect more clarity by August when we comment on our half year numbers. By then it should be clear if Total was successful with the top kill of the leaking well at Elgin and further progress on the completion of Skarv including the situation regarding utilization of the planned staff capacity at Skarv.

In the meantime, we have decided to provide you with a worst case indication. Should both fields not produce at all in the remainder of 2012, our total 2012 North Sea oil and gas production is expected at around 7 million barrels of oil equivalent. The planned production of around 38 MBOE from Yuzhno Russkoye in Russia remains unchanged.
That concludes my remarks and I will now hand back to Sascha.
Thanks Marcus. Operator, we are now ready for the Q&A, so please register the questions.
Thank you. We will now being our question-and-answer session. The first question comes from Mr. Vincent Gilles from Credit Suisse. Please go ahead, sir.

Yes. Good afternoon, everyone. I've got two questions and a request. I'll start with the request to make myself popular. Can you please make sure you don't change the reporting in the next quarter? It would be nice because it's all a bit complex to understand where your gas earnings are going.

But assuming I understand what you talked about, my question is could you help us extend to the full year the delta of €340 million that you talked about for the first quarter in terms of renegotiation of gas contract. And maybe extend the discussion a bit on the real impact of if you succeed or do not succeed in renegotiating your contract with Gazprom? And then, maybe update us a bit on the amount of loss we should expect for 2012 and 2013? So that's a long question but I guess it's a simple one.

The second one is on – very simple on the tax rate. Given the very low tax rate in the first quarter, should we assume that you will be below the 30%, 31% you indicated at the fiscal year 2011? Or should we assume that it's going to still stay as close to the 30%? Thank you very much.

Let me take the second question. I could not understand the first question acoustically. But Sascha believes he understood what you were asking. On the tax rate, in our outlook we still assume a tax rate at around 30%. The one item I would like to highlight is that if some of the risk on the E&P side materializes that will of course have some negative impact on EBITDA but it's at the same time will most likely have a positive effect on the tax rate. So on an EPS basis, a negative development on the E&P side is slightly dampened.
The first question I believe was related to gas but I just couldn't understand it.

Yeah. Then – so I give it a start and then Marcus puts the finishing points to it. You started by talking about the EBITDA delta for Supply and Sales, which is indeed to the tune of €340 million in the first quarter. For the full year, we told you that our expectations for gas Supply and Sales 2012 is inline with what we have reported in 2011, i.e. negative to the tune of €700 million to 800 million absolute, i.e. a delta of zero, which means that if you want to align the first quarter with full year that delta of positive €340 million will level out to zero in the full year. And then to the Gazprom negotiations, Marcus?

Yeah, maybe just a bit. Please bear in mind that last year we recouped in the second quarter some of the losses that we had incurred earlier. The situation with Gazprom is I would say as we reported in the context of our pre-results we still have sort of two routes that are being pursued. One is the arbitration proceedings, which we expect to come to an end around the end of the year or early next year.

At the same time, we are continuing to have discussions with Gazprom outside arbitration proceedings. These discussions are constructive whether or not they will lead to an outcome we will have to see. And I think this is what we can – only thing we can continue to reiterate at this stage. Ex, of course, to the point and for sake of clarity, in our outlook, we are – segment – not assuming any result from an arbitration or a negotiated solution with Gazprom.
And finally, Vincent, your request regarding the statement structure is not only noted, but it's understood.
Thank you very much.
Your next question comes from Mr. Lawson Steele from Espirito Santo. Please go ahead, sir.
Yeah. Hi, Marcus, a couple of questions (29:37)...
Lawson, we can't hear you, I'm sorry.
Is that better there. Can you hear me now?
Yes. Now we can hear you.

Okay, sorry about that. I beg your pardon. And just a follow-up on gas, if the gas price worsened, what will be impact on the profitability of the two-thirds of the contracts, which are already re-negotiated? That's the first question.

Secondly, as you point out, you dramatically increased your hedging for 2014, both in Central Europe and Nordic. Am I right in deducing that you've done that because you are bearish on coal prices and/or you believe there is no chance for carbon set aside? So if that's correct, can you enlighten us to why you are bearish on coal prices? Thanks.

All right. On your first question, basically the development of the gas oil spreads during the remainder of the year has hardly any material impact for us. We only have a very small two digits terawatts our open position there. So it's no meaningful impact. On the power hedging for 2014, quite frankly, what happened here was we observed and to a large extent that was in January and then also partially in the context of the coal spread quite a lot of liquidity in the markets, and we just took advantage of that. Now I would say by now, from my perspective, that looks not to unintelligent what we did during that time, but it was really not that much driven by us taking kind of a very bearish view on the developments, we just saw the liquidity and took advantage of that.
Okay.
So you should not interpret this is us being bearish on the coal price that would be a wrong interpretation.

Okay. Good, can I just pick you up on one thing you had mentioned before to Vincent? You said you expect the arbitration to be through by the end of this year, beginning next year. Is that – is there a specific date or something you can hang your hat on there? Or is it just sort of general feel? Because there's always seemed to be a sort of loose interpretation there will be arbitration which finishes some time in 2013, but now you seem to be a bit more specific on timing.

Yeah. Look, I mean, first of all, there is an understanding between the two parties as to how long its supposed to take and then by now it is driven by the time table that the three arbitrators are setting and that is pointing to a resolution in this time window that I mentioned.
Okay.
Yeah. So.
Thanks very much.
Thank you. The next question comes from Mr. Patrick Hummel from UBS please go ahead sir.

Yes, good afternoon, everybody, two questions please. A couple of weeks ago you gave an interview to the German Boersen-Zeitung and you were saying or you were quoted saying that you have identified further potential asset disposal candidates and that the €15 billion target could well be exceeded. Could you just add a bit more color on that? What kind of assets you're thinking about? And what order of magnitude we're talking about here?

And second question you probably have already met the analysts from the rating and credit rating agencies in the past few weeks and might have a certain feel what could happen and what is unlikely to happen. Could you just share with us your latest thoughts on your credit rating and the meeting you have had so far? Thank you.

Yeah, on your first question regarding the €15 billion, basically I made that statement in the context of the observation that when you actually look at what is publicly known by now, namely that, yes, indeed, we are working on a disposal of Open Grid Europe, yes, we are working on disposal of Energy from Waste; and yes, we are having discussions on E.ON Westfalen Weser and there's maybe also a few other things, if you add up all of that that was in the observation of the journalist, which was not entirely incorrect, you might very well end up north €15 billion. And that's the only thing that I confirmed; that indeed it might be that we end up north of €15 billion.

This is not a function of us now having gone out and we sort of proactively look for more things. We have always said that we will achieve the €15 billion and we also always said that we also feel comfortable about this because we have multiple options, in terms of what we can do. Now if we see attractive opportunities, strategically and financially, to exit an asset, we will pursue this. And by now, I would say I can't rule out that we might exceed the €15 billion.
Okay. But there's nothing that has basically of the – another portfolio read you whatsoever would have become on top on your disposal list or anything like that?

Now, yeah, so this is how I think you should think about the €15 billion. Now, as it relates to the conservations with the rating agencies, we are basically in the process of the normal annual conservation with them. There is nothing spectacular to report about this. We made it clear that we are comfortable to be able to achieve the disposal program. Clearly, an important topic in the discussion is our ability to execute our cost-cutting program, which we laid out in more detail to them, gave them an update on where that stands. And clearly, I think what also matters here is our continued commitments to take the debt factor down to a level below three times. And so I have nothing spectacular to report about this.

I mean, it's clear from the discussion with the rating agencies that during the last 12, 18 months their assessment of the sector as such has gone in a direction where they look at it in a sort of more careful way, let me put it this way. You've seen it recently and it was also a case for E.ON that, in particular, when they think about the business profile of a company in our sector they tend to take a sort of a more cautious perspective here, but this is something that I would say we have already been impacted by that. Others have more recently been impacted by that, so, again nothing exciting to be reported about.

Yeah, I would add in terms of the risk assessment what is obviously also supporting the discussions that we have with them is any progress we have made or we will make in the future when it comes to the gas renegotiations.
Okay. Thanks very much and great job on your hedging.
Okay, next question.
The next question comes from Mr. Benjamin Leyre from Exane BNP Paribas. Please go ahead sir.
Yes, thank you and good afternoon. Two questions, please. First one, back to Gazprom, do you still view the recovery of the past losses since Q4 2010 as a pre-condition for any deal with Gazprom?

And the second question is related to the still quite weak situation on the key spots pricing at Continental Europe, can you update to us on your plans to do some power plants mothballing is in your future? Thank you.
Okay. The answer to your first question is, yes, of course. We clearly see the recovery of past losses as a core, if not the core ingredient to any solution there.

As it relates to the development, I mean, the poor development of the spec portfolio and more specifically there certain power plants, which by now don't look really profitable, basically, I can only reiterate what we have been saying, namely we are now – we are doing analysis on a plant-by-plant basis. And I would expect that in a number of markets that will lead to specific actions. But we will of course first discuss this or communicate this to the relevant authorities and inform them. But that is kind of the normal process that we are now entering into. And of course, I will not speculate here about how many and which power plants; that would not be a smart and might also lead the market in a certain direction, which of course we can't do.
When you speak about the relevant authorities, do you mean the anti-trust authorities or the Bundesnetzagentur [The Federal Network Agency]?
No. I mean, what we – the authorities we need to inform are in the respective markets and this may happen in several markets or several states. It's regulators and transmission operators.
Thank you.
The next question comes from Mr. Peter Bisztyga from Barclays Capital. Please go ahead, sir

Yeah. Hi. Good afternoon. Two questions from me, firstly, on your E&P business. Could you give some indications of how you expect profitability at Yuzhno Russkoye to develop this year, given higher oil indexed pricing in the pricing formula? And also if you – once you renegotiate your Gazprom contract, would that have a negative impact on profitability at Yuzhno? So that's kind of question, number one. And question number two was could you just remind us what the benefits of going from an AG to an SE are please?

Yeah. Okay, well, first of all, on Yuzhno Russkoye, production volumes we expect to be at last year's level. And as it relates to profitability for the full year, last year, we were around €460 million and we would expect that to slightly improve on the back of better prices. And the negotiations on the long-term contracts with Gazprom have nothing to do with Yuzhno Russkoye. They are absolutely not correlated and as actually never been mentioned by anyone in the conversations.

Now the advantages from moving from an AG to an SE, I mean, in the main advantage that we see is that it is much better reflection of who we really are. You will see this, for example, when you just will observe who will be represented in our Supervisory Board, where we will continue to have also employee representatives but they will now be sourced, not just from one country, but from basically all the countries that represent E.ON. We find this way more appropriate because we are no longer just a German company. When you look at actually where the growth is coming from it is clearly predominantly from outside this country. So that's one of the big points that we see. There is no real cost in establishing the SE. We think it also allows us to create a Supervisory Board size, which we think will be more effective going forward in its discussion and challenging of the Management board and those I would say are the main reasons.
Thank you.
Thank you. Your next question comes from Mr. Alexander Karnick from Deutsche Bank. Please go ahead sir.

Yes, hi, thanks for taking my question. Just following onto the Skarv and Eglin problems, I mean, you gave a number of volume downside, which you can make a calculation; it's maybe €300 million on the top line. But what I was after is what sort of this top-line effect, whatever you come out in your calculation, would that be fully an effect on EBITDA? Or could you confirm that part of the costs at this year are related to actual production, so that the EBITDA impact is probably lower than the top line? And may be as a follow-up in that context, could you be more specific on the reduction of the group tax ratio, which sort of your worse case scenario would imply?

And then, I would just ask the second question is on sort of your mothballing strategy. I appreciate you don't want to be specific for the obvious reasons, but would you confirm a view to say, look, if you're on the one-hand side trying to save €1.5 billion of cost through 2015, you would probably refrain from running stations that are clearly cash loss making and are far from returning into the money any time soon? Thank you very much.
Yeah. I mean, on the last one, yes, I mean, that's the key driver of the analysis now and we will take action on those plans that we really see deeply out of the money.

On your first question regarding Skarv, as you I think are indicating indeed the revenue loss will not be the same as the EBITDA loss. I mean, essence there was going to be a substantial delta between the two numbers, which is, yeah, 50% or so of that, not more.

And then, as it relates to the group tax ratio, honestly speaking, here I prefer to really give an update when we have the clarity on the specific fields and we can do a reliable math. We depend – I mean, the worst case scenario that I mentioned if that's really happens then the impact will be north of one percentage point, yeah, but whether it's then two or three percentage points here we still need to do the analysis.
Okay. Thank you very much.
Thank you. The next question comes from Mr. Bobby Chada from Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead, sir.

Hi. Good afternoon. I had a really follow-up on Skarv and Elgin-Franklin. The first question relates to some of the details you gave on Skarv with the riser issues and accommodation and government approval issues. First of all, can you confirm that you have enough capacity with contractors and the necessary vessels to meet the timetable to your satisfaction? And can you give a bit more color on what the issues with the government approvals are?

And then my second question is just to clarify, you helpfully gave a worst case scenario for Skarv and Elgin-Franklin production. Am I right to assume that worst case scenario is included within the bottom end of your guidance range?
